39817219.review:
This won't be short, so I will jump straight to the gist of the problem with Spark the Electric Jester. The game is good… great even, but it was buried alive by the technical problems.

Here's the quick guide how you should handle things, if you will be still interested in the game after my assessment. You get it and are very careful not to pass 2 hours of playtime first time booting it. If you notice any performance problems during this time, you should probably refund it before it gets worse. Technical issues aren't universal and many people are enjoying a functional game, but FPS drops and many other problems happening are by no means rare. Dev publicly stated that he is unable to fix those and there no patches are in works. Game delved to the realm of unplayable one too many times for me to, sadly, not issue a negative review. No 2D game should have such problems sapping the fun out of it!

Then, you may ask me, why I eventually beat the game...

Yes, I struggled through moments when FPS count dropped below 10. That is because, firstly, I'm a fricking stubborn and tenacious guy that won't review the game without beating it and can take some punishment, and secondly, when it works, the game itself is a joy to play. It's far from perfect mind you, but it's nothing that should be easily passed.

Spark's strength lays it the way how flowing and responsive the gameplay is. Keeping its Sonic fangame root at its sleeve, similarly to Freedom Planet, it provides the joy of movement and zooming through stage and enemies with grace, power and speed. Mechanics and physics differ somewhat from those in Sonic and Freedom Planet, so while the game sometimes feels shameless with inspirations, it doesn't feel like there was no effort put into mixing things up.

Good movement, decent controls and somewhat cohesive level-world building are the strong points that helped me power through the frame drops providing bundles of enjoyment when the game didn't felt like it's falling apart in the technical sense. Soundtrack also adds up to the experience, with varied tunes that stay fresh the whole game, despite quite big level count.

While soundtrack is indeed polished, the game itself lacks the shine quite noticeably and it extends further than mentioned technical difficulties. While most levels are very good with mixing things out and pulling interesting gimmicks, later stages start to lose a lot of steam in terms of originality and good design. They can feel very samey and blocky if you play for the extended periods of time - constantly repeating some high-speed setpieces and strongly reusing earlier enemies and ideas.

Discoverable powers that Spark can weld are mostly fun and interesting, but some really feel underpowered for the tasks at hand. Bosses look intimidating, but they are very pattern-based, damage-spongy and are easily disposed by the brute force. Also, dash works very strangely and sometimes it [i]reduces[/i] your momentum in many instances. Story is insane and art is very inconsistent at many spots.

Some of those faults are mitigated by the additional inclusion of second, unlockable character. He has less health and no Jester powers, but it's equipped with insane mobility options and very forgiving parry mechanics. This makes level traversing and boss fights much more dangerous and interesting endeavors. You are actually are forced to learn patterns of enemies and going into fights without a plan and attention will kill you quite fast. This additional mode would be an all-winner if not for the mediocre damage output you are stuck with, but it's still interesting to see unlockable character that feels like it fits the game better than the main one!

That was a long litany of issues and problems, but that's what Spark really is. Even without framerate problems, it feels very inconsistent and duct-taped, but it would be a giant lie if I would ignore the big bag of goodness that game provides or tries to provide. You can see through all of it - it's not an amazing game, but it's made with effort and good sense for high-speed platforming action that is noticeable despite gameplay and presentation issues.

This still won't make me change this into a positive review. Framerate issues are too prevalent and intrusive to ignore and the inactivity of the dev will not help this game get any recognition for the time being. This is quite sad if you think about it. If you feel that Spark could be something you would enjoy and if you too are fan of Sonic, Freedom Planet or other action oriented platformers, give this a shot. Use your refund option if you end up as unlucky as me or enjoy the game if it decided to work for you.

This really shouldn't have ended like this.

[i]Like this review? Consider [url=https://twitter.com/NBlastMax]following me on Twitter[/url] so you could be notified about new reviews I post on Steam.[/i]

様々なゲームへのリスペクト溢れるが、何よりもソニックリスペクトが強いスピーディな2Dアクション。
ステージのギミックもスピードを殺させないギミックが多く、慣れればノンストップで駆け抜けることも可。

道中に置いてあるコスチュームを拾うことで攻撃方法や機動力が変わり、ステージの地形や敵の戦闘など状況に合わせて切り替えることでスムーズに進められるようになっている。
特にコスチュームの一つであるWingはソニックのようなスピン状態になれるため、坂道で使用することでスピードがぐんぐん上がっていき本家同様の爽快感を楽しめる。
なお先ほどのWingやFireなどダッシュ中に攻撃することで異なるアクションを繰り出すタイプのコスチュームや、攻撃をチャージすることで壁にくっつくことが出来るようになるなどコスチュームによって行えるアクションはかなり異なるため、見知らぬコスチュームを手に入れたらポーズ画面を開いてアクションについて確認すると更に楽しめるだろう。

ストーリーは英語テキストが中心なのでその点は注意。ゲームとしてはストーリーわからなくてもアクションゲームとして楽しめるので幸いか。

本家ソニック同様一部ステージではどちらに進めばいいかわかりにくいなどの欠点はあるが、2DアクションとしてはMDやSFCばりの硬派なアクションが楽しめる。BGMも良質でサウンドトラックもbandcampで配信されているので是非。

39631783.review:
I feel like this game fixes fundamental flaws in Sonic and Kirby by cherry-picking the mechanics that it takes from each, and adding its own. I really enjoy Kirby games (and Sonic Mania), but all Kirby games feel too slow for me, aside from Squeak Squad. And both Kirby and Sonic are always too easy. This game starts out at about a Kirby-Sonic difficulty and stays that way for a while, not picking up until the final areas. But once you win, you unlock a different character, who can't use the different powers, but is pretty awesome anyway with a more complex moveset than any single Spark ability. And his versions of the levels contain new hazards, new enemy placements, a few changed level sections to make you use his abilities where Spark needed help from stage mechanics, and harder bosses (plus a few totally new ones). He also has less HP, so with all of that, it quickly picks up the difficulty where the first campaign left off. And then there's the third... you gotta do that again as Spark (with help where needed) with very little HP, and one of the other character's essential abilities has been replaced with one that works well, but requires very good timing. By the time you're done with that (and the special challenges) the first campaign is just a (pretty dangerous) playground. The replayability comes from how fun it is to make use of the quirks of the various abilities (which you can choose from whenever you want at that point) such as their different levels of mobility, and the cool "charge up a super attack by landing hits a lot" mechanic. Not the kind that has a long animation and completely wrecks everything, just a nice boosted version of certain attacks from certain copy abilities. And as a result, it charges much faster. It's mainly used for bosses, but I can't complain since there are so many, and they too are playgrounds (they have set paterns, so that's why they can be treated as playgrounds instead of serious challenges). My point is, I love making use of all the different mechanics and whatever 2 powers I have with me to be really fancy (one goes into storage whenever you use the other) which could not be done to nearly as much of an extent in Sonic or Kirby, and there's a challenge here for hardcore people (which I do fall under the category of).

As for the framerate drops that many people talk about, I only get them on rare occasions, and always in the same places. Other than the first section of level 13, where they persist until I beat the boss (it's just a few minutes of a lagless low framerate) it's literally just a few moments where the game has to lag for a couple of seconds. As long as the demo runs well for you (it's not hard to find online) I'd assume that the effects would be as minor for you as they are for me.

Oh, and there are a few minor annoyances in the form of bugs, but nothing that can't be easily dealt with. Trust me.

39452948.review:
Spark the Electric Jester is a fun experience for players who just want to get in and have a fun ride. However, more technical and completionist players will probably not enjoy what this game offers.

To put it short and simply, Spark is essentially "What if we gave Classic 2D Sonic Kirby Powerups and Megaman X Mobility?" It's a unique take on a 2D Platformer that works surprisingly well.
The Music sounds fantastic for every scenario and stage and the Level Design is crafted around the core gameplay with hidden goodies for players who like to explore and rewards players for playing good.
Unfortunately, the 'Kirby' element of the game also comes with some of Kirby's same trappings.
For example, there's an ability you can get called Gravity which essentially is a big tooteloo to the stage because you can fly literally everywhere with the thing.
The game also uses Kirby's same mentality for difficulty. After beating the main campaign, you unlock a new one with a different character who has different gimmicks and less health, Basically like the Meta Knightmare modes from Kirby games. Then, there's the challenge run where you have even less health as the main character in the second character's stages. If that wasn't hard enough then guess what, Completionists? You unlock the special challenges where you need to play through certain stages with brand new gimmicks that can make you wanna toss your controller through the wall. I won't go into detail about each of them, but let's just say that what you get after beating those challenges is NOT worth it. Especially since those challenge modes reveal the game's biggest flaw: gameplay hiccups. One time when I was playing the game normally after doing some of the challenge modes, I found myself in a challenge-moded level even though I was just playing the main campaign. That and quite a few other technical and graphical hiccups start appearing while you play the challenge and campaign modes in a single sitting. To be fair, since the game is pretty long, it's doubtful that many players will run into these problems unless they marathon the game in one sitting like I did, but these are still glaring issues that need to be fixed. Besides that, this game is lots of fun, has lots of replay value from it's many modes and powerups and has a fantastic soundtrack. Worth its asking price, for the most part.

39429735.review:
Holy s h i t.

I went into this game thinking it would be, "Eh, okay." But I was fucking wrong. Lakefeperd's Sonic fan games were okay, but had a lot of problems. A lot of bugs and really poor level design. That being said, I was expecting more of the same. This kid upped the ante ten fold. Not only is this game polished with no bugs (from what I've found,) but the level design has improved tremendously. 

There are a lot of power ups that mix the gameplay up, and they're all fun to use for the most part. This game compliments people who have skill, giving people who are good at the game the ability to blaze through levels, like your typical Sonic game. 

There are a ton of moments in this game that got my adrenaline pumping, trying to see how fast I could go and how long I could maintain that speed. The boss fights are fun and sometimes a bit of a challenge, but the game nevers gets too difficult. The game borrows a lot from Freedom Planet, but I don't mind that very much. 

The music is on point. Its at the quality of what I'd expect from a 2D Sonic game. Thats how good it is, especially some of the tracks in late-game. 

If you love fast paced platformers, you owe it to yourself to try this. Presentation-wise, its a little rough around the edges, but I'm all about gameplay, and thats where this game exceeds all my expectations.

I'd go as far to say that I enjoyed this game even more than Sonic Mania and Freedom Planet. And THATS saying something. This game is amazing. 

10/10, please make a sequel, Lakefeperd.

39297435.review:
Un peu trop fouilli, Spark échoue à être Sonic - il ressemble plutôt à Zool. Avec ses deux scènes cinématiques propement dégueulasses qui, en plus d'être aussi laides qu'un poux crevé, arrivent aussi tardivement qu'une cheveu sur un bol vide, il échoue à être cool. Parce que certains niveaux s'étirent trop en longueur, il échoue à être rythmé. Parce qu'il y a çà et là quelques craquelures et autant de soucis de finition, ce jeu échoue à être massif. Parce que son level design n'est pas souvent brillant, [i]the Electric Jester[/i] échoue à être culte.

Et il y a tout le reste. Il y a ces arrière-plans somptueux qui nous torturent, nous, les pauvres cons qui remuent le stick de gauche à droite comme s'ils jouaient à un party-game, tiraillés entre cette folle envie d'accélérer pour en déshabiller les parralax et le désir de se figer pour les contempler tel un mari voyeur qui, détournant les yeux de sa fenêtre, se surprend de trouver une femme nue dans son lit. Il y a cette générosité de contenu qui ne fait jamais désordre, ces décors variés qui se suivent avec assez de cohérence pour qu'en les traversant on s'imagine un monde et ses histoires. Surtout, il y a ces musiques qui nous régalent presque autant qu'avait pu le faire [i]Hill Top Zone[/i], nous enthousiasment, nous piquent, nous chantent qu'elle nous aiment. Spark ? Beaucoup de jeux ont les mêmes défauts, peu ont ses qualités.

Beau en tout mais magnifique en rien qui ne soit formel, Spark n'est pas aussi génial que les récents mastodontes de la plate-forme. Génial, il ne l'est même pas du tout. Pas invité dans le carré VIP à se saouler avec Freedom Planet, VVVVV, JumpJet Rex, Super Meat Boy ou Downwell, [i]the Electric Jester[/i] devra se contenter du deuxième chapeau, celui juste en-dessous, celui de ces jeux qui nous plaisent, celui des ciels où les étincelles sont d'autant plus belles qu'elles sont rares, celui des jeux que nos MegaDrive auraient adoré rencontrer.

39219869.review:
So, this game is a hidden gem.
You like the classic 2D Sonic games? This one is absolutely for you. Its stages even have similar elements such as loop de loops, or the bouncy mushrooms from Sonic & Knuckles.
However, even though this game wears its inspiration on its sleeve, don't let that fool you. Spark has absolutely a lot of unique mechanics. The biggest one is the fact that the namesake of the game can collect various powerups that allow you additional mobility or increased combat abilities. Since the character transforms in some of them, I was reminded of Kid Chameleon. But don't be fooled, the base form also is quite capable of combat.

Its biggest flaw is that it might be a bit too easy if you like playing 2D platformers, however, there's additional modes that you can unlock that ramp up the difficulty a lot more.

Add to this an absolutely excellent soundtrack.
Underrated, for certain. This game is great, and I heavily recommend anybody who likes platformers to check it out.

39153651.review:
An addictive mixture of Sonic, Kirby and a little bit of Megaman X thrown into the mix that captures the vibe of the 16-bit era platformers. Its foundation as a Sonic fangame cannot be hidden, as some amateurish level and sprite design can be seen in some places.

Overall, though, it's a solid package that it's heavily recommended if you enjoy any of the series the title draws inspiration from, or just action-packed 2D platformers in general. However, do not expect the polish of an AAA game by any means.

39052269.review:
This is how you do a retro throwback right! On the surface this looks like it's just cribbing the same old tricks of others trying to do their own version of Sonic, but this takes a lot of great ideas and puts them together wonderfully.

Take Kirby's power diversity and utility, sonic's speed, and a little of Freedom Planet's combat and we're in business.

That's not to say it's unoriginal, just saying it does a great job of taking elements that feel familiar but adding them in a fresh way. 

All that and the fact it's got a killer soundtrack, a fantastic sense of flow to the movement, and it's supremely pretty.

38945793.review:
This title showed up in my recommended titles list, and being a Sonic fan, when I saw the gameplay bore a striking resemblance to the classic side-scrolling Sonic games, I immediately got it. It's a fantastic game! The visuals are beautiful (though I personally think Spark's design is a little bland), the music is fantastic and the game seems to be a mishmash of all the best parts of other classic games. You've got the speed and movement of a Sonic game, the ability to change your powers with pickup items like in Kirby: The Crystal Shards and the attack execution of Megaman (including wall jumping).

The controls are very responsive and I personally didn't experience any of the graphic lag some folks have reported, save for one moment in a boss battle where I launched a charged attack while my opponent was launching theirs (my latop is not made for gaming either - it's kind of a POS, honestly). There are also little details that just really bring the game together, like when Spark goes into his Cool (Ice) form and any water under him turns to ice, not allowing him to sink, which can be both good and bad, depending on whether or not you want to go in the water to collect/kill things. 

Also, this is not an OMG hardcore game. I'm a very casual gamer and I suck at most games, and even I didn't find this to be a challenge. But sometimes you don't want to play something that beats you into the ground (I've got Cuphead for days when I'm feeling masochistic). You just want to buzz through something pretty and fun without wanting to chuck your controller through the wall. If that's what you want, Spark is the game for you. I wasn't specifically looking for something super-challenging, but I'm just pointing this out because some players may tire of this game in a hurry if they're looking for something really difficult.

My only issue with the game is there doesn't seem to be a way to save your progress. There are checkpoints (TONS of them) and the ability to restart from a checkpoint while in-game, but if you quit the game to the main menu or close out of it entirely, your progress isn't saved. There seems to be a level select menu, so maybe it's some kind of a bug? No clue, but for the time being, it seems that if you want to see the entirety of this game, you have to be ready to beat it in one sitting and I have no idea how many levels there are.

But all in all, I really like this game and I would absolutely recommend it, especially for folks who like the pace and handling of classic Sonic games with a twist.

A game by the team that made Sonic Before the Sequel and Sonic After the Sequel. Staring the Titular Spark the Electric Jest that had his Job taken from him by a robot revolution of sorts. 

Spark runs, jumps, dashes, and attacks through many stages with a very versatile array of powers that can be found through out levels from blades to gravity everyone of them are fun to use in their own way. Personally I was a fan of gravity and edge traversing stages with those are very fun.

Something people have not mentioned is the Fark story mode after beating the Spark story

If Spark is sonic + Kirby + megaman X.
Fark is Devil May Cry Royalguard style


Fark takes only 3 hits and has a super meter that can be built with Parrys. Thats right theres a parry system that can get you some,alot, or even lose meter if you mess up. Meter can be used to get into Fark's super mode for skilled players. Or in a pinch  Fark can unlock his limiter to get full life back, temporary invinciblity, and a speed boost. 

Whiles Fark's levels are the same at Sparks they get Fark exclusive routes and certain moments you swore that you didnt see as spark but then again the levels are very vast. (even without birds for scale I'm glad to not see) 

Levels are long, fun, and engaging with fantastic music. Average level can take 10 minutes for your first time through but can beaten faster with skill. 




Negatives~These are very minor but noticable

There are points in the level where certain object in 2 levels hurt you and later are background so I got small heart attack seeing a metal fan return.

Spark and Fark control very well except for a strange momentum when slowing to  a stop. For a split second characters keep walking after letting of keys or thumbsticks go. There a slight slippery which was present in their previous games. 

I've mentioned how fun the long levels are. But after 3 or 4 during a sitting I felt exausted and had to comeback to beat more levels. But if you like long levels it great but if you don't or not have the energy it might have cause for burn out.

If this game ever gets patched or updated I would suggest an easy and hard difficulty. Hard being the current game and easy is 5 minutes of each level. Just to get the hang of these levels.


 

After all of it I am invested in the Spark fanchise. Its a series I will speak highly of to others about it. left a very positive impression on me and I can't wait to see what the next game will be,

38625013.review:
If you did not get enough platformers in 2017 with Sonic Mania, then Spark might be the seasonal surprise to brighten up your holidays and to continue the Mania. While it is not intended to be a carbon copy of Sonic, Spark: The Electric Jester blends the level-design and overall playfulness of Sonic with additional features inspired by other 16-bit classics. Like the success behind Freedom Planet, what started as years of Sonic fan-projects ultimately blossomed into a developer’s own spark of inspiration that has created a new beloved platforming icon with not only this gem but also a Sonic Adventure style Spark game planned in the future.

To be quite honest, if I did not know this game was created by the same developer who made Sonic Before and After the Sequel, I would have thought Spark: The Electric Jester was a new IP from a new in-house from SEGA. Back when everything wasn’t about Sonic and SEGA branched out with other IPs like Ryster, Vectorman, etc. Spark isn’t simply a great game as an imitator of the past; it takes all the lessons learned from mastering what makes 2D Sonic games so great, adds its own deviations from other classics, and creates a truly memorable platformer that plays to all these referenced games’ strengths with few, if any, of their weaknesses. If you wish to show SEGA that classic Sonic’s designs remain timeless, then supporting games like Mania as well as fan-projects turned into new IPs like Spark and Freedom Planet are what you should support to bring about that change.

[h1]Spark! The Cyborg ‘90s Dream; Glory to New-Formed IP![/h1]

This is a game that feels like the SNES/Genesis era never died with its conglomeration of ideas lifted from Sonic, Kirby, Mega Man X and dozens more classics mix-mashed into what may first appear to be too radical of a dream to be true. Instead of being an absolute mess, Spark manages to blend all these elements surprisingly well to create an experience that feels like a time-machine of all that was loved from ‘90s gaming crammed into one game.

As previously mentioned, level-design and the overall playfulness of sandbox-like levels from Sonic are combined with Kirby’s copy ability given a new spin where each weapon offers a distinct playstyle that can shape how boss-fights are played out. In addition, boss battles take a page from Gunstar Heroes/Freedom Planet where they are massive spectacles that breaks up the platforming focus of the standard levels. Difficulty balances nicely with both player skill and knowledge of move sets tied to abilities that will help to tackle bosses more easily. Movement abilities like wall-jumping, double-jumping, etc. are also mad-libbed from Mega Man X to make Spark feel very versatile while also adding more decisions on the two loadouts you select between Spark’s many hats. Lastly, there is also an ability to ride a hoverboard—you could not make Spark anymore ‘90s if you tried, except for adding Pokémon into the distillation of all that was loved from the past

The most important thing to remember is that while Spark largely borrows many influences it does not one-hundred percent recreate them. It was admittedly difficult to unlearn how Sonic’s momentum should work on slopes as Spark’s normal speed and momentum does not one-hundred percent recreate them. It’s not game-breaking, yet it seems strange for a modder who has made Sonic games for over a decade not to get the physics right. This issue is compensated towards the later half where speed boosters help adjust Spark’s movement to be more Sonic-like, so I have to believe this decision was deliberate. This can also be said of the Copy-ability being limited to many different hats with no combinations nor does Spark always have the same move sets as a steady progression like MMX. These all feel like concessions made to make Spark play as a distinct character. which is easier said about his gameplay than his actual personality and storyline.

[h1]Light is Faster Than Sound, Or Why Someone May Appear Smart Before Speaking[/h1]

When it comes down to the make-or-break deal of platformers, gameplay always triumphs over good storytelling and world-building, yet games like Sonic 3 & Knuckles as well as Before/After the Sequel showcases they can be as effective to communicate a narrative. Simple stories like Tails and Sonic becoming friends and using foreshadowing techniques in silence does not ruin the pace of platformers, and it can often tell an effective storyline because of its simplicity. It somewhat baffles me that the masterwork you see in the developer’s previous creations are forgotten for his own IP.

Unfortunately, Spark feels like a confused attempt to tell an overarching storyline between Spark and Fark (another robot replacement). What should be a campy, stupid plot feels like it missed what made the storylines of the Sonic Mods so beloved. Spark's narrative combines a convoluted plot of robots uprising because of some primary protocol about handling humanity while at the same time staying simple to the initial set-up of a robot losing his job to another robot. Some of the dialogue is admittedly so cheesy it’s entertaining, but it makes me wonder how much better of a narrative Spark could have been had the game used only its visuals to tell its story. Perhaps in an attempt to make Spark stand out as a character, the game’s tone makes him out to be too much of a comic relief icon. Even Fark’s journey remains largely the same as his epilogue story is simple another means for the player to enjoy more time in these levels from a different perspective with new mechanics that make him a much harder character to play. It’s quite a shame the narrative quality from LakeFepord’s previous works from about the narrative was otherwise lacking, but perhaps it was to focus more so on the core gameplay.

[h1]It’s Not What You Are That Matters; It’s the Watts You Make That Shine[/h1]

Minor gripes, gameplay and story related, aside, Spark manages to breathe something new beyond appealing to Sonic fans as a passion project. Chances are if there is some aspect about the game that appeals to you this game will quickly become a modern classic as it doesn’t excel as one idea from the past but a conglomeration of the old as something new. The level-design, power-ups and both Spark and Fark’s modes offers enough replay-value to satiate any fan, and there are additional challenges to incentivize skilled players to master the game. There is simply too much to love not to give this strange looking robot a chance to prove himself. 

Whether I think Spark stands the test of time or is a greater platformer than Sonic Mania or Freedom Planet is irrelevant because the qualities that make it distinct are worth playing no matter which one is the best. The fact that these modders have made their debut, big or small, shows us that classic-style platformers have never lost their touch, only their spotlight was lost. The potential all these games show is that the horizon only is brimming with future possibilities, and thanks to Spark, the future of modern 2D and 3D platformers appears to shine even a tad more brightly with innovation.

This game [i]looks[/i] like a lot of fun, but it simply does not work.

It has massive, seemingly unexplainable, performance issues that have it running at a constant choppy crawl of less than 20fps. Judging by the Steam forums, these issues have been common for the last six months (since at least April 2017) and there are no definite, cure-all fixes.

36344463.review:
Spark the Electric Jester is a game about Sparky Sparky Boom Boom Man, a Boom Boom Man who's working a minimum wage job despite having a college degree. One day robots take over the world. One of the robots is Farky Farky Foom Foom Fan, a clone of Sparky Sparky Boom Boom Man who decides to be a little fark and take Sparky Sparky Boom Boom Man's minimum wage job from him. Since Sparky Sparky Boom Boom Man kinda farking hates life anyway, he decides to go fark up the farking fark who took his farking job. Oh and also there's something in there about Not Sigma and Not Dr. Light, but they're not as important.

I forget where I first heard of this game, but I know that it had something to do with Freedom Planet. And, you know, since I love Freedom Planet so much, this game kinda felt like a given. I for one don't think this game is as good as Freedom Planet (and I swear I'm not biased... probably), it has quite a few issues, and all around the game could really use a new coat of paint so to speak, but I still find it enjoyable despite that. Pick it up if you have the fifteen bucks laying around or find it on sale.

[b][u]The Good Stuff:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*][b]You can go [i]fasssssst.[/i][/b] Like, ridiculously fast. That is all.
[*][b]The power-ups are a whole lot of fun.[/b] They add a lot of variety with their abilities and their different methods of fighting and traversing stages, and the method for acquiring and switching between them works really well. Chances are you'll take a liking to two or three and those will be pretty much the only ones that you use, but it's a lot of fun to mess around with them all.
[*][b]There's no lives system.[/b] You'll always respawn at your last checkpoint, including if you quit the game. Whether you prefer this over having a lives system is going to come down to you, but it certainly keeps the game from kicking your butt too much.
[*][b]FARKING FARK THE MUSIC IS AMAZING.[/b] It's mostly electronic, but there's also some orchestral pieces, as well as a wide variety of genres that all fit each stage to a T. You'll probably find yourself bopping your head to the beat. My favorites are Smog City, Mare Desert, and Megagraph Fleet, the latter of which is, just, objectively the best song on the soundtrack. It's fantastic.
[*][b]The narrative is kind of hilarious??[/b] It's like the game's creator knew that he probably couldn't write something very good, so he just made something completely ridiculous instead. Spark barely takes anything seriously, he lampshades everything, all of the antagonists are total hams [i]including[/i] the big bad, and there's just such a blatant lack of effort put into everything, it's amazing. The sense of humor might not be for you, but I'll tell you what, after a [i]certain other game[/i] totally screwed itself over by trying way too hard, it's nice to see a game that doesn't take itself so seriously.
[/list]

[b][u]The Bad Stuff:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*][b]The controls feel kind of weird.[/b] At first I thought it was just me and my Freedom Planet bias, but then I looked at the other reviews, and... yeah, the controls are weird. It feels really floaty, especially in certain forms, and it makes platforming more difficult than it should be.
[*][b]It feels like there could have been some more thought put into some of the forms.[/b] Some of them have movesets and/or controls that could use a bit of touching up. Gravity and Cool come to mind. On the topic, it also feels like there could have been some more thought put into [spoiler]Fark[/spoiler], because his controls feel really weird, especially the [spoiler]wall/ceiling mounting[/spoiler]. All around the game kind of feels like it could have really benefitted from taking advantage of more than two buttons. But I digress.
[*][b]Some things in this game just take way too long to happen.[/b] Specifically, level transitions tend to be a long time of sitting on a black screen, and sometimes after you defeat a boss it will just sit there for a while before it actually plays the defeat animation. I don't know if this is just my computer sucking or an actual thing, but... it definitely happens.
[*][b]This game is absolutely full of sound bugs.[/b] As in, I first noticed this the [i]first time[/i] I played the [i]first level.[/i] Sometimes there's music when there's supposed to be no music. Sometimes there's no music when there's supposed to be music. Sometimes it will accidentally start playing the wrong song and then suddenly say "oops" and start playing the right one. It also tries to do this cool thing where the music cuts out just before a boss room so it can be replaced with the boss theme, but sometimes there are still other things to do before the boss room, so you're just running around without any music wondering if this is a glitch or intentional.
[*][b]Some of the cutscenes feel like they go on too long.[/b] I mean it's not like we're reaching Freedom Planet levels of [i]ugh,[/i] and frankly there aren't even that many cutscenes in the game, but sometimes the characters will start talking and they won't... stop. It really breaks up the pacing.
[*][b]Also the cutscenes still play in Time Attack mode????[/b] Why??????????
[*][b]I kind of wish there was more world building.[/b] Take a look in the game's art book and you'll find all kinds of information that isn't in the game, about the world and the people in it and the origins of the robots and Jester Forms. I just think it would have been nice if some of this was actually present outside of a manual, but... maybe that's just me.
[/list]

Like I said, I do think that this is a good game, despite its flaws. I mean, it's fun! And those beats are totally jamming. I think it's possible to look past the flaws, if maybe it doesn't make it as easy as Freedom Planet does. Like I said, I recommend giving this game a try. If it's not for you, it's not for you, but I've certainly had a good time with it.

很好奇这样一款看着挺有趣，评价又是特别好评的游戏，为何居然看不到一个中文评测。
可能是酒香也怕巷子深吧，多少也让我疑虑。但既然能够抢到中文评测的沙发，让我吃次螃蟹也无妨。
最主要是万圣节打折，只卖19，不好玩也不怎么心疼。
这款游戏之所以偶然看到后能让我加入愿望单，主要也是游戏标榜的浓厚16位MD游戏风格
明眼人一看，这个游戏就是模仿索尼克嘛，实际一玩，也确实很索尼克。
其实制作者完全没有忌讳这一点，而在游戏中，经常都能在一些细节上看到制作者对SEGA和MD的爱。
但是游戏前期的索尼克味不是很重，飚速的部分不够多，反而是大量需要跳跃技巧的平台。
于是第一版的抢先评测中我是认为该作不是那么“索尼克”
但是玩了六七关之后，渐渐开始感受到本作的优秀之处
关卡的自由度，速度感慢慢表现出来，确实非常索尼克。虽然折磨人的跳跃比重仍然偏多，但也是一款值得让人竖起大拇指的精神仿作。

本作另一个特色就是变身系统了。倒也不是很新鲜了，比较像FC上的费力克斯猫和星之卡比系列。吃了道具之后不但攻击方式会改变，还能得到相应的特性。
各种变身，不少区别度不算太大，类似卡比那样比较随意。
本作大概是想结合高速系统，让玩家体验行云流水的操作，但是视频里的骚操作，可有些太难了。
不过至少，一边冲刺，一边砍杀还是蛮爽快的。

34430725.review:
Spark the Electric Jester is an indie game meant to be like any other 16-bit game but more specifically, Sonic The Hedgehog, Mega Man X and Kirby Super Star. I decided to buy this because, well, LakeFepered, and I must say, he's gone at it again. I'll explain each story and other tid bit in this review so sit back and relax as you read this review for your own enjoyment.

[h1] Spark's Story [/h1]
Once upon a time, in the planet of...
Well, there are too many names for this planet, call it whatever you like. Anyways...
there was a Formie [4me] named Spark. In his whole life, he had his job taken away from him every single time until he went to Jester School, got a degree there (I don't see why not), and became a Jester. That was until guess what, another robot, one which seemingly looked like Spark himself, took the job. (Spark nicknamed the robot Fark) Spark then just quit the job buisiness after that. But not long after, all the robots in the city have suddenly gone on a rampage and Spark just happens to be curious into what is going on, so he goes on anyways. And since Fark is among those robots too, Spark also felt like this was the greatest oppoturnity to take revenger on Fark and eventually get his job back!

Now on to gameplay.
Spark the Electric Jester plays similarly to mostly Sonic and Kirby games. You got your speedy speed, you got your [b] Cool [/b] power-ups such as the aftermentioned Cool Jester, the Electric Bat for starters, the Wind Jester for mobility (a lot Sonic-y if I must say) and many more. But other than that, you also have charged attacks in the vein of Mega Man where it's the simple way of holding the attack button you Mega Man fans remember and love to do! (There's also Super Charged attacks where you keep attacking enemies until you fill up the blue bar, then try to do a charged shot) The levels themselves have a lot of variety but mostly cliched that I might not to have to go through them. You can see those for yourself in those screenshots. The bosses are a mixture of easy and hard and are not too hard to master (with the slight exception of the last couple of bosses). So that means it's important to learn about every power-up in the game that can potentially help you in your run wothout dying a lot. Speaking of which, there are no lives in this game, which means you are free to die as much as you want. [spoiler] After completeing the story, you unlock "Wishes Mode", where with the press of 2 buttons, you can choose any power-up in the game except for one that you unlock by 100%-ing the game. [/spoiler]

Phew, I feel I talked about enough in that section up there. Below this sentince are some extra story information so if you want to find out about the other stories on your own, skip to the non-spoiler section down further below.

[spoiler] [h1] Fark's Story [/h1]
After Spark saved the planet from being rid of from any life forms, he uses all the prize money he got from saving the formies to go to the Himilayas (yes, apparently they have one of those in this planet). Spark invites Fark to stay at his house after Fark turned to the good side. The story starts a month after the first story's ending when one day, Fark was just chilling at Spark's house until he saw that the other robots were on a rampage once again. Fark goes on to investigate on why this is happening.

Fark's gameplay is entirely different from what you expect from Spark. Basically, think the Meta Knightmare mode of the modern Kirby games. Introduced in this new story mode is parrying which is similar to that of Bayonetta. (Did I mention this game could have modern gaming references?) Having Fark's Story be like the Meta Knightmare mode of Kirby games means Fark does not have and cannot use [strike] certain [/strike] power-ups in the game. But with having these new abilities comes some great pros. If you keep parrying/attacking, you fill up a static bar (similar to that of Spark's), which you can use to restock on health, become invincible for a short period of time and have stronger attacks. Although, when you get the bar up to the max, you become Super Fark who's not that different from his regular form, except for having longer range in attacks. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] [h1] Spark's Challenge [/h1]
A new VR game based off Fark's has been released, and Spark decides to play it. But being that guy with attitude, he turns the pain to max and that's how the story starts.

There's not really anything to say about this mode, except you play through Fark's story with Spark who has 2 health points only. (wow, way to put a coincidencial Mario reference there) It is, however, the hardest mode in the game as these stages are tailored for Fark rather than Spark but it's possible to win the game mode with a bit of practise. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] [h1] SPC Challenges [/h1]
The last game mode in the entire game is the SPC Challenges, 10 challenges set up by another robot, Romalo. There are 9 challenges for Spark and just 1 for Fark. If you finish them, that would count as 100%-ing the game, then you will unlock the unlockable power-up in wishes mode. (If you haven't 100%-ed the game, you'll only get to use the power-up at the end of Spark's story) [/spoiler]

[h1] Time attack [/h1]
Spark the Electric Jester also has a time attack mode for the first three modes of the game. You don't really get anything for doing these so just enjoy them.

[h1] Some issues [/h1]
Spark the Electric Jester, sadly, suffers from framerate issues that sometimes hinder the experience. Even the developer doesn't even know how this happens and doesn't intend on fixing it soon.

[h1] Overall thoughts [/h1]
Overall, this is a pretty good game with a great soundtrack and I highly recommend getting this game if you can stand framerate issues. It's very unique compared to some other games out there. I would give this game a [b] 9/10 [/b] .

Thanks for reading and enjoy the game!

34418762.review:
It wasn't surprising to me that this was a good game because I'm familiar with Lake Feperd's previous fan works--with his Sonic After the Sequel being the best Sonic fan game that I've ever played. 

What was surprising to me, however, was just HOW GOOD this game was! It has great control. The levels are large, beautifully parallaxed environments. It's fast but has great platforming to balance it's momentum. The bosses are engaging. The music is phenomenal--possibly one of the best video game soundtracks that I've ever heard--better than Freedom Planet--hands down! 

Because of games like this and Freedom Planet, Sonic-inspired momentum-based sidescrollers should definitely be separated into their own genre. 

Pros:
+ Good balance of speed and platforming
+ Huge levels that are mapped both vertically and horizontally.
+ Absolutely amazing soundtrack--one of the best in recent years in my opinion.
+ Power-ups that are unique and give the gameplay variety
+ Boss fights go from being "not too bad" to "WHOA." (You have to play to see what I mean)
+ Story is amusing but not the focus.

Cons:
- Framerate/slowdown issues at times
- (In my opinion) Could use some form of special or bonus stages with rewarding unlockables.


Bottom line, if you preordered or plan to get Sonic Mania, I HIGHLY recommend this one. If you are a fan of Freedom Planet, definitely get this as this is different in a VERY NICE way. 

And don't wait for it to go on sale, either. This game is WORTH $15 if not more. It's THAT good. Support this guy so he can make more good stuff like this.

9/10 - Would hunt down the robot who stole my job again. 

- LB

XBOXコントローラー使用。
高速移動と様々な能力の装備で攻略していく2Dアクション。
ソニックやカービィ等の要素が混ざっている。

飛ばしても良質なアクションゲームとして楽しめた。
ボリュームが思っていた以上にあり、
BGMも豊富で良曲が揃っている。

イベントシーンの絵は若干盛り下がった。

ステージに置かれてる装備を拾うことでアクションが変わる。

知らない使い方をしている装備があった。
（下に矢を放って滞空できるarcherや　
攻撃ボタン押しっぱなしで壁を走れるedgyなど）

1週目のメインモードは難易度が低め。
セーブポイントと回復アイテムが多数ある。
即死もほとんどないので
何度も同じ場所で死ぬようなことはないだろう。
雑魚敵は瞬殺かスルー。ボスはだいたいごり押しでも勝てる。
スピード感を重視しているゲームバランス。

2週目の別キャラモードは難易度が少し高め。
壁歩き、二段ジャンプ、空中ダッシュと優秀な移動法を持ち、
相手の攻撃をタイミングよくガードすることで
数秒無敵+ゲージ増加する優秀な防御法を持つ。
（ゲージが貯まることでHP回復、攻撃強化が発動する。）
ただし装備がなく、範囲の狭い近接攻撃で戦うしかない。
1週目よりHPが低く、敵も強化されているので
1週目と同じ感覚でプレイするとすぐ死ぬ。
敵の攻撃の予備動作に注意して、ガード中心の戦いに
慣れていけば十分攻略できるゲームバランス。

3週目のハードモードはあきらめた。

34139257.review:
The immediate comparison, aside from to Sonic, is to Freedom Planet, as they're both retro-esque 2d platformers that borrow heavily from genesis-era games. Though Spark is more a mixture of sonic, mega man x, and kirby than anything else. It certainly plays great and the characters feel great to control, especially the wind jester. Honestly the game should've been renamed Spark the Wind Jester since that's the power I found myself using 80% of the time - the other 20% being using the electric bat to fight bosses. That's the thing, there are a few powers that are very obviously the best and the others go unused most of the time as a result. There just aren't a ton of viable options.

The level design in this game also feels... unnecessarily drawn out, more often than not. Stages tend to get quite long but also a bit repetitive and samey, with ideas constantly being repeated just a little too long or sections going on a bit longer than it feels like they should. This is especially noticeable when you're going through the game the second or third time and it gets hard to tell what's what in each level. The bosses though, well, in the normal playthrough you can just mindlessly barrel through them all with no problems but in the second and third campaigns they do get fairly tricky to fight but usually pretty satisfying to complete - there's one or two that feel a bit bleh, and a few others that are easy no matter what, but for the most part they provide a satisfying challenge.

The presentation of this game is also pretty good on the whole. The various level themes are all pretty diverse, with a few of them feeling kind of bland (and the theme of the first two levels in particular looking a bit ugly - it's pretty unchanged since the original kickstarter demo though I think, which could explain it, but it almost feels like FM Canyon could've been cut entirely and the game wouldn't suffer for it at all, the only level that doesn't have any unique qualities and it's half the length of every other level as well). But in generall the game looks pretty good and there are some levels that look quite great. It's pretty reminiscent of the games it's influenced by, maybe just a bit blockier. And the soundtrack, holy heck, it's really fantastic. I can't really think of a single song I disliked and there's just a ton of great songs, every level has its own theme that fits it really well & a lot of these are just great standalone tracks. There's also the theme for the extra bosses in the second and third campaigns which feels like a pretty great Crush 40 tune honestly, really gets you pumped and makes those difficult fights more tolerable.

The biggest nitpick I have is that there are a lot of weird technical issues. The timer when switching between level segments will reset to whatever it was the last time you hit a checkpoint instead of persisting across screens. In Luna Base, the checkpoints in the first area reset time for some reason, and when you die you get to see the game, instead of reloading, rapidly scroll to where you are. It feels really hacky, to say the least. There's also the music of Turbulence Plains, which reverts to the theme of the previous stage after the midboss of the level (but resets to the correct music if you die after. And there's one of the challenges in the game's mission mode where if you die the first time through (INCREDIBLY likely given that it's a one-hit death challenge) the game resets the map but adds in some extra hazards that were intentionally taken out of the level to make the challenge less frustrating. So yeah, woops. And these are all just the ones I can remember off the top of my head, I'm sure there's more.

But overall? Yeah, I did enjoy this game. It can feel a bit easy by the start but gets to a comfortable difficulty by the end of the first campaign and ramps up in challenge substantially from there. And the campaign itself is pretty lengthy - 16 levels of varying lengths, several of which can take over 10 minutes to clear. There's' a fair amount of bang for your buck, and speedrunners will probably have a field day with the movement tech possible thanks to the wind jester (I have watched a run, it's a really cool looking run). And even without really "replaying" anything (just going through each of the campaigns) I got 15 hours out of this, which, for a $15 2D platformer, is completely fair. There's really not much keeping me from recommending this, all the issues I have are minor at best, and while I would say check out Freedom Planet first if you haven't, this is only a step or two behind that game and very enjoyable in its own right.

34098695.review:
If you want some Sonic action, then this...might be worth maybe looking like. The game tries very hard to hone in on the feel and theme of the blue hedgehog, but fails on really nailing what makes those games tick. Spark plays similarly to both Sonic and Kirby; Sonic because you are running through colorful levels with a good deal of speed, and Kirby because you can find power ups to fight with.  The problem lies in how nearly everything is executed.

First off, Spark doesn't hold momentum properly. Unless you are using Air Jester or the Hoverboard, your top speed is quickly reached on foot, but as soon as you hit an incline, you lose speed incredibly quickly. There is a dash feature you can use to power through it, but it's not smooth. Further more, it is possible to reach speeds faster than dashing, and the dash doesn't scale to your speed. So you can dash to actually LOSE speed. Unlike Sonic, you have a health bar and it almost doesn't matter. I played through the entire game not really caring about taking damage because there's alot of enemies simply tossed directly in your path while trying to run. I only started actually dying in the last two stages or so, and even then, I was doing the bare minimum.

Fighting is also kind of clunky. You pick up power ups and can store two of them to switch between. Most of the powers swing heavily between super useful or only okay. For example, the Mage Jester is great for covering large horizontal distances with damage. However, Edgy Jester is only alright with it's short range and kind of bad damage. The Air Jester power is almost worthless for anything but traversal and the Ice Jester is so rare that it might as well not even be there.

The game's story is easily the worst thing about it. A few typos litter the text and in general, it's hard to care about anything because hardly anything is ever even explained. The game's art style is...odd. In the game, it looks perfectly okay. I'm not much of a huge fan of Spark's overall character design but I can deal. What I can't deal with is how bad the cutscenes look. They look really unpolished and almost like they came out of MSPaint. The music is easily the best part of the game, although I'm not really going to go look up an OST anytime soon.

Ultimately, the game is kind of underwhelming for me, but I really think that if the Devs decide to do a sequel, they'll get it right. They're already so close!

A really freaking awesome game that captures the great things about platformers from the 90s while offering a further degree of freedom and style. The game as said takes inspiration from 90s platformers and off the top of my head, there's a dash of Sonic, Kirby, Shinobi and Megaman X. You can definitely feel the sonic aspects found in the speed and stage design, the power up mechanics from kirby, wall slide and jumping from megaman x and shinobi, and then throws references to all sorts of games with the power ups (including shinobi on one of them.) I'd even say there's a reference to some fighting games as I noticed a move equivalent to Marvel vs Capcom 2 Guile's Somersault Kick. This isn't just in the moves either but sometimes the mechanics too.

What's really cool is just how you can go through the stage multiple times not just for the alternate paths but to playthrough with different powerups. The power ups effect a lot of your movement options and sometime can be used in ways you wouldn't think to at first (like thinking a move is primarily for attacking but it's secondary purpose can be used creatively to cross a gap from the attack's forward momentum or upward boosting momentum.) There are times I literally want to go through a certain section a certain way and this game just literally incites me to alone through it's design. 

The music is pretty awesome too and quite catchy. It really captures the moment and matches well with each stage too. I couldn't be happier to listen to the soundtrack even on its own.

The sprites are also pretty cool and some of the basic motions change slightly depending on the form Spark is in as well. (try looking up and down, you'll see what I mean.)

Overall, it's a great game to play! Don't pass it up!

(people have also mentioned something about fps drops or whatever. Maybe that was before or something but i've never had a single issue with the speed.)

33538844.review:
A unique, fun platformer for fans of the genre. Spark has some pretty clear influences from Kirby, Sonic, and Megaman X, but it still manages to set itself apart from those games and feel like a fresh experience.
This game encourages you to learn the game's mechanics, and if you struggle at any point, it is very forgiving with it's frequent checkpoints and infinite lives. If you prefer to go fast, you can blast through the stage by using things like the dash, Spark's midair blasts, and the plethora of skills the power-ups like Wind and Edgy give you. If you prefer combat, you can fight enemies all you want, and explore the stages at your own pace. Spark's a game that's easy to learn and play, but hard to master. 
Spark also has a fantastic soundtrack, done by Falk, who's worked on LakeFepard's Sonic fangames, and he's also done work on Kingdom Hearts 2.5 HD ReMix and Sonic Mania. (!!!)
If you're looking for something to tide you over until Sonic Mania, try this game out. If you're a disgruntled Megaman fan who's dying for Capcom to finally make a new Megaman game, try this game out. If you like Kirby but would like to try something new, try this game out. If you want to try out a platformer for the first time, try this game out. Spark really is a fantastic indie game, and deserves a lot more attention than it's getting.

Resumo: COMPRA ESSE GAME! Você não vai se arrepender! 
---- 
 Comprei esse game junto com Sonic 4 episódios 1 e 2 e Sonic Mania. 
Enquanto 15 de agosto não chega (data de lançamento de Mania) fui jogar Sonic 4-1... Meu deus, que horrível a experiencia. Precisava esquecer esse game! Desculpa o hipóbole, mas é a verdade. 
 Então sobrou esse game, Spark, pra ser o "anti-depressivo" das jogatinas do Sonic 4 episódio 1. E digo que o game me viciou pra cacete. 

  Já conhecia o trabalho dessa equipe (dando foco em LakeFeperd) desde dos fans game de Sonic, que são surpreendentemente bons e agradáveis de jogar. Spark é a mesma coisa.
É inegável a comparação aos games Mega Man e Sonic nesse titulo, por conta de usar upgrade + velocidade. Mas o game tem o sua originalidade que é raro de ver hoje em dia por ai. 

----

Prós:
Trilha sonora, animação (em alguns momentos), gráficos (padrão 16-32 bits) e level design.

Contras:
Animação da caixa de diálogos (isso é uma critica inútil, mas me incomoda) e Upgrade jogado nas fases de primeira, esperava jogar um por um e ver a necessidade de usar, que nem em Mega Man.

33313509.review:
Imagine if Sonic, Mega Man & Kirby had a baby... and then that baby was kicked into outer space and mutated into a force of complete kickass awesomeness. That, ladies and gentlemen, is Spark the Electric Jester. One of the most fun games it's been my pleasure to play in quite a while.

Now I haven't played much Sonic the Hedgehog. Only the first two way back when; so maybe some of that magic is lost to me. But this game still has plenty of charm.

The fast-paced gameplay and intricate level design of classic sonic coupled with the combat of Rockman and upgrades system of Kirby mixed with one of the most energetic, kickass soundtracks I've heard in my life. This game has rocking tunes for every occasion.

I enjoyed every moment of the main campaign and look forward to completing the side campaign and the other bonus modes!

It would be remiss of me to neglect mentioning the potential framerate issues on some systems. I've heard many complaints about Spark the Electric Jester running sluggishly even on the beefiest of systems - GTX 1080s & whatnot. On this dingy Intel HD GT1 laptop, though, it only dipped in the final few stages.

In conclusion: Spark the Electric Jester is a [b] MUST HAVE [/b] game for fans of retro games, thrill-seekers and newbies to the genre alike. It perfectly captures what made the games of the olden days so great and ramped that up to 11.

33305862.review:
So I started following Spark in its early stages after learning the creator of Sonic BTS+ATS was working on his own game. I sorta forgot about it after playing the alpha, and with little fanfare, it came out shortly after. I'm surprised it hasn't recieved very much recognition since its release, given that Lake's previous work was pretty popular, but I'm sure somebody from the youtube community will eventually spread the word. Anyway, review time:

[h1] THE GAME [/h1]
is overall pretty fun. Others have accurately pointed out that it's a game with momentum-based platforming, kirby powerups strewn about the levels, and a bit of Freedom Planet combat. Also included is a dash button that MOSTLY helps to build and maintain speed, but more on that in a moment. This game definitely did a good job of tiding me over while I wait for Mania/FP2, though I think it lacks enough polish to compete with the other [strike]games[/strike] game of its type. I'd recommend it to anybody who likes going fast or is a fan of a certain blue meme machine.

[h1] PROS [/h1]
+ Given all of the musicians who worked on Spark, the soundtrack was of course going to be amazing. Many of the tracks stuck with me after completing the game, and I'd totally recommend checking out the album on Bandcamp or just following the musicians on their respective soundclouds etc.
+ Spark's art is overall really nice. I think Lake does a great job of illustrating scale with each stage's backround, and I especially like how much bustle there is in the more urban stages; it really feels like the levels aren't just empty racetracks to run around. Some of the levels are a little clown-vomity, but more color works better than less in retro games.
+ I love all of the little references here and there, like the Mushroom Hill-style shrooms, the lava stuff and trains from BTS/ATS, and the DNA beams and the giant teal death-laser from Freedom Planet.

[h1] CONS [/h1]
- I love the idea of access to a bunch of different powerups, and while some of them were fun to use, I thought a lot of them were not that great. I ended up racing through a lot of the game with the board power, mostly because both its vertical and horizontal are pretty insane, and I kept the knight power for all the bosses. I liked a select few others like the baton and the aptly-named "edgy" power, but some of the others that lacked mobility seemed inferior to the knight's damage and OP shield. Additionally, I felt like we got an overload of powerups towards the beginning of the game and there weren't that many towards the end, which made me more inclined to just hang onto the two I had. I liked some of the level-specific interactions they had, like walking on lava with the fire powerup, and I wish there were more of those to coax players into trying out different ones.
- Without a score-system, killing enemies is pretty much a waste of effort. They occasionally drop health, but I found that just jumping over everything was a lot easier than potentially losing life by sticking around to kill all of them.

[h1] OTHER STUFF [/h1]
• The dash mechanic is fun to use, but it doesn't seem to do anything whatsoever when spammed on flat surfaces; you only gain more speed when mashing it while going down slopes. I suppose its main purpose is to gain some momentum from a standstill as well as going uphill.
• The bossfights are occasionally a bit wonky. The first few guys are same-y and pretty much die instantly, though the later bosses do get more interesting. The Kerana Forest boss was the only one that I died to more than once, mostly because some of Spark's attacks push him off the side of the map. [spoiler]I thought the Fark fight was cool, but a little underwhelming. Also, the final boss was difficult until I figured out you could just cheese him by flying above him with that spin-attack for most of his sequences.[/spoiler]
• Filling the revive-gauge-thing takes a long time, and I only ever used it once. I guess it was a cool mechanic, but I didn't get much use out of it. Without lives, I'm not sure what else you could implement anyway.
• One of the reasons the game doesn't feel polished (for me) is the general buggy-ness that occured during my first playthrough. On the second part of the Smog City level, I somehow flung myself into a gigantic empty void that ultimately led to the bottom of the level, which wasn't programmed to kill you. Not sure if it was part of the level, but I didn't come across it again. Other kinda annoying glitches include losing momentum in pipes that launch you around by getting hit by stray projectiles and the weirdness that comes along with dashing.
• I didn't have any problems with the framerate, but I usually play 2D platformers on a keyboard because I'm a weirdo and I think only controller people had issues.
• I guess the cutscenes were alright, though quite clearly low-budget. They get the job done, and we don't have to deal with questionable voice actors.

[h1] IN CONCLUSION [/h1]
The game isn't perfect, but it still holds its own; after all, you get to run fast through colorful stages and smash stuff. The fighting mechanics work well in this game, as bossfights where your only attack is to jump can get boring or even trivial if not executed correctly (see Sonic CD). I wish there were more developers in the momentum-based 2D platforming market, but I guess people are still worried of accusations of creating another sonic clone, even though we really didn't see anything of the sort years after the sonic games of the pre-2000s. Hopefully this game and Freedom Planet are proof enough that people still want retro platformers of this sort, and maybe someday we'll get a wave of new developers who are willing to expand the currently limited supply of games in this sub-genre.

33173614.review:
I thnk Spark the Electric Jester is a bit of an interesting case. It's one of those games where you [i]know[/i] it's flawed, but you just can't bring yourself to dislike it.

The game is an interesting blend of Sonic, Kirby, and a bit of Mega Man X. Although there may not be as many abilities as you'd find in a Kirby game, the amount provided is fine and the new gimmicks in each level keeps it from feeling monotous. And for this type of game, there's a quite nice number of levels, too, some of which can go on for over 10 minutes. Whether that's a good or a bad thing is up to you; I personally didn't believe it caused it to drag, but that's just myself.

Another neat thing are the different modes. I don't want to spoil anything here, but there's some really neat unlockables that completely change the way the game is played, and if you felt the main campaign was too easy, you'll find what comes after to be much more difficult.

But, as I said, the game is definitely flawed. There are typos galore, a completely broken timer on a certain stage, some framerate issues, and overall it feels like more polish could've been applied. Heck, at one point the game crashed after completing Stage 13 on the second campaign, which I'm not really sure how that happened.

However, don't let that deter you. As I said, this is an incredibly enjoyable game if you can get past the flaws and I highly recommend playing it if you enjoy platformers. The artwork is great, the soundtrack is phenomenal (I'm literally listening to one of the songs right now), the gameplay is fast-paced fun, and there's a ton of replayability. I seriously recommend playing it.

33150698.review:
[h1]Resumen nivel 5:[/h1]

¿Aburrido? ¿La espera para Sonic Mania y para Freedom Planet 2 se está haciendo muy larga? ¡Spark es tu solución!

Puede que lo haya dicho con tono de vendedor, pero es cierto, Spark The Electric Jester es un pequeño diamante en bruto que vale la pena probar y disfrutar si estás esperando ansiosamente la llegada de esos juegos. En tu primera partida la dificultad puede ser un poco esquizofrénica (especialmente con los jefes), pero nada que pueda destruir tu experiencia. Eso sí, estén avisados de que [b]hay algunos problemas con el rendimiento del juego[/b], que al parecer son cuestiones ajenas a LakeFeperd y están más relacionadas con el ClickTeam Fusion y el motor del juego. Yo principalmente [b]he sido uno de los afectados por los terribles bajones de frames[/b], que al parecer están relacionados con Windows 10, mi gamepad y el motor del juego, pero no por ello voy a condenar al resto del juego. También hay [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VwACcGgRKoI]otro bug particular que encontré[/url], que no es nada severo, pero podría ocurrirle a más gente y parece ser algo que Lake se olvidó de programar, espero que esté leyendo esto y lo pueda arreglar.


[h1]Análisis completo:[/h1]

Llevo siguiendo a LakeFeperd desde Sonic Before The Sequel, en 2011, y también esperé muchísimo la llegada de Sonic After The Sequel allá por 2013, así que cuando anunció que su primer juego oficial iba a ser Spark The Electric Jester me sentí realmente excitado. Los años fueron pasando y Lake fue sacando algunas demos de Spark en Kickstarter, las cuales juegué a más no poder, hasta que el día llegó. Y aunque me demoré unos meses en comprarlo, tarde o temprano iba a hacerlo igual.

En fin, la historia de Spark es bastante típica (Spark pierde su trabajo, todo el juego es Spark tratando de recuperarlo), pero tiene sus giros inesperados (Spark termina metido en algo muchísimo mayor) y tiene su dosis de humor consciente de sí mismo, al final de cuentas Spark y los demás personajes conocen de los clichés que hay en los videojuegos de este tipo, lo cual le da personalidad al juego. Lejos de seguir una fórmula tradicional, Spark busca mezclar, modificar y hasta burlarse de ella. Sin embargo hay un detalle que al parecer sí lo toman en serio, y lo único que puedo decir sin spoilear demasiado es que si jugaron Freedom Planet entonces ya saben qué esperar del villano de Spark.

Luego está el gameplay, y acá es donde la mezcla extraña de Spark cobra vida, tomando elementos principales de Sonic y de Kirby, pero también con elementos de Mega Man X y Freedom Planet (que a su vez está fuertemente inspirado por Sonic y Gunstar Heroes). Spark corre, salta y tiene su especie de dash, todo esto que puede ser complementado por una serie de powerups que hay en todos los niveles y que Spark puede tener hasta 2 guardados al mismo tiempo para ir alternando sus habilidades. Esto permite una variedad de estilos de juego sorprendentemente elevada, y puede hacer la aventura más fácil o más difícil. Al atacar a los enemigos, Spark puede cargar su barra de estática, que básicamente es la carga para un ataque especial que dependerá del poder que estés usando en el momento. También hay una mecánica en particular que no he visto que muchos hablen al respecto, y es que al juntar suficientes "cosos" con forma de rombo se cargará otra barra adicional, que permite revivirte automáticamente cuando mueras. Además de la campaña principal hay otros modos de juego (desbloqueables tras terminar la historia de Spark) que modifican las mecánicas y juguetean más con otras ideas.

En el departamento de la dificultad Spark no es muy difícil (incluso con los poderes adecuados puede ser realmente fácil), pero sí va a exigirte que sepas usar bien sus habilidades ya para el quinto o sexto nivel. Los jefes pueden ser el aspecto más "esquizofrénico" (como ya mencioné al principio), porque a veces pueden ser realmente difíciles y a veces ser patéticamente fáciles. Aquellos que son difíciles pueden ponerte los pelos de punta, pero no he tenido demasiados problemas en vencerlos. La dificultad se acomoda moderadamente bien, a diferencia de Freedom Planet donde llegado a cierto punto el juego no te perdona un solo error. SPOILERS: [spoiler]El jefe final de Spark es el mejor ejemplo de esto que digo, porque no es taaan difícil a comparación de Lord Brevon en Freedom Planet. Brevon se llevó más de 30 de mis vidas la primera vez, mientras que el jefe final de Spark me mató una sola vez. Y eso me parece bien en un sentido, porque Brevon podía llegar a ser realmente frustrante, pero al mismo tiempo siento que el factor sorpresa que el jefe final de Spark tiene queda opacado cuando te das cuenta que es como pelear contra Brevon.[/spoiler] Lo único que puedo decir de este spoiler que escondí es que la música es realmente muy buena en ambos casos.

Finalmente, y como estaba hablando en el final del último párrafo, la música es [b]genial[/b]. Muchos de los compositores de Sonic After The Sequel regresan, y hay también alguna que otra cara nueva. Funk Fiction en particular se manda un trabajo espectacular en mi opinión con [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1zgEAV4C2Us]Luna Base[/url] (que suena similar a Red Moon, un tema en particular que hizo para Sonic ATS), pero los demás también hacen un estupendo trabajo, son todos músicos magníficos.

Así que espero que con este análisis haya brindado una mirada más amplia del juego y de por qué lo recomiendo. Capaz no cubrí todos los aspectos importantes, pero son cuestiones que en lo personal quería hacer llegar, y tenemos que darle soporte a LakeFeperd, nuestro hermano brasilero.

32979768.review:
Personally, I'm not huge fan of 2D platformers. Very rarely do I enjoy 2D platformers, and I can tell you now that Spark the Electric Jester is one of few 2D platformers that I enjoyed. 
The gameplay in STEJ is a combination of Sonic the Hedgehog, Kirby, and Mega Man X. It has the speed of 2D Sonic, multiple abilties to change gameplay from Kirby, and the multiple gameplay aspects from Mega Man X (wall jump, dash, charge shots). If you enjoy at least one of these games series, then you should try out STEJ. The platforms in areas fit the theme, and the music only helps out the stage. Thats something I need to talk about, the music. The music in this game is incredible. Theres not one peice of music that I hate, and I constantly listen to all of them. If your not interested in the game, try listening to the music, as I would have bought the game just for the music. 
The replay value the game has is a lot. Due to having multiple abilties, you can replay stages (or the entire game) with just one, or no abilties. Along with that, there are other game modes to pick, which I won't spoil, but your'll need to unlock them. Its a mystery! 
Depending on how you play STEJ, is how difficult it becomes. For my experience, it was easy, but only because I knew how to use Sparks abilties to its fullest. The game gives you a tutorial, but it doesn't show everything (such as how dashing at the right time can cause you to take no damage, trust me its good to know this). Theres no touch damage (for most enemies anyway) in STEJ, and THANK YOU for that. You can try to avoid enemies, but there will be times when you trying to avoid them, will cause you to get hit. But if your skilled, you can avoid these situations. 
Its a shame that this game isn't insanly popular. I've done some research, and from what I gathered, the timing for the kickstarter, along with the realease of the game were at very bad times, and this game hasen't sold well due to bad luck. I hope this game becomes a success later on, because I love this game. Its ones of my most favorites game of all time, and I dont even enjoy 2D platformers much. I would really like to see a squeal, or a port to consles for this game, but apperently its not going to happen. Still, I'm a huge fan, and hoping for a huge rise in sales for this game! I highly recommend it, so pick it up!

32956882.review:
After the release of Freedom Planet (one of my favourite games of all time) and the Sonic CD, 1 and 2 remasters, I had very high expectations of any title being worked on by a former Sonic fangame developer. This game came on my radar because the mastermind originally worked on critically acclaimed fangames like Sonic: Before The Sequel.

Based on this, I decided to pick it up, and already something feels really off.

First of all, let's start with the physics. The most important part of any mascot platformer is the physics and this game gets them completely wrong. Spark feels floaty, loses almost all of his forward momentum in a split second when he tries to run up steep hills, has trouble running up loops that aren't tiny, and often ends up in weird situations where he will end up jogging up or down a wall instead of sliding along it to walljump, or even start jogging on the ceiling - which is somehow even more physically impossible.

On a related note to this, Stage 05's constant suggestions to 'GET DASHY' are quite comical, if you consider the fact that the only way to give Spark any decent momentum on hilly terrain or a loop is to spam the Dash button.

Next are the various powerups that Spark can obtain in each level.The only one that really feels like an improvement to his basic moveset is the bat, which extends the reach of his attacks and allows him to do a rolling attack in the air. Other ones like Wind, Board and Mage feel like they significantly downgrade Spark's moveset and make him much harder to control.

Charged attacks with the Wind powerup do no damage, but they have significant recoil, knocking you away when you charge up and unleash the attack. While this can be useful for gaining momentum, it requires you to constantly turn backwards so that you can exploit the recoil. Mage allows you to charge up and perform a Kamehameha wave, although it gimps your mobility significantly, makes Spark vulnerable to enemy fire, yet still deals very little damage. The board powerup allows Spark to move faster - something which would have been welcomed in his base form - but removes your ability to perform a charged attack.

Finally, the level design is good in places, but is overall quite bad. Some levels force you to wait for slowly moving platforms, while others will have traps like spikes or springs at the end of a long corridor which you're supposed to run through. It's the classic 'trial and error' gameplay we saw in a lot of modern Sonic games where you're punished for running at breakneck speeds by having no time to react to obstacles in front of you. The best example of this is the end of Stage 3 right next to the goal. Couple this with framerate issues, and you have a recipe for disaster.

However, to say something positive about the game, it does have a phenomenal soundtrack.

32174047.review:
The lag issue that plagued my version of the game has been fixed (somehow), and after 15+ hours put into this game I can safely say that Spark is well worth your time & money.

Unfortunately, that lag issue is still there & the dev has said that he still doesn't know how to fix it, so if you're going to buy then be patient with the game (that's what I did at least, and the lag issue just disappeared completely for over a month now. Just don't have much/anything running in the background and i'm sure the game will still stay at a smooth framerate.).

With that said, its time I finally give my thoughts on the game.

[b]Plot[/b]
I am glad to say that this game has a good plot behind it. Spark's journey is all about getting his job back, and not really about saving the world from a robotic takeover. It has its humor & doesn't take itself too seriously (unlike another Sonic-inspired indie game...), which is really refreshing.

[b]Presentation[/b]
This game looks amazing. Character sprites are fluid & animated well, and the enviornments Spark travels through feel like big, fleshed-out areas of his world. Also, this game's soundtrack is PHENOMINAL!!! It has its Genesis callbacks, rhythmic basses, and anime battle themes galore, which gives this game a diverse soundtrack that's worth listening to, even if you've never played this game before. Overall this game presents itself really well.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
As I've said with Freedom Planet, the game is almost entirely worth buying just for the gameplay alone, and this game is no exception. The control is very responsive & fluid with Spark's movement & attacks. Speaking of which, its time to actually talk about the game's protagonist. Spark can do quite a lot in this game. He can wall jump like Mario, dash like X (Mega Man X to be exact), and use copy abilities like Kirby. Also he can run like Sonic, but that was kind of a given since this game is obviously Sonic-inspired. The power-up system is diverse & provides great combat oppertunities for the player, which I for one enjoy. The only fault I have is with this game's stage design. Its either too confusing, to lengthy, or a mix of the two. It really makes the game drag on for far longer than it should. Besides that, this game is still worth its price.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Spark the Electric Jester is a fun game with a simple plot & a wonderful presentation to back it up. Despite its massive issue with lag, it is well worth your time if you can make sure it doesn't lag too much. I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a fun, action-packed game that's on par with Freedom Planet & Sonic the Hedgehog.
